ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really enjoyed the course in the sense that it taught me how to develop clear arguments both in and outside class. In addition to writing 7 essays in this class (including response memos, midterms, a debate statement, and a final), we had many interesting discussions on the history and theory of nuclear proliferation. I particularly enjoyed the first half of the course which focused on Nuclear Crises between 1945 and the early 2000s.
I learned a bit about game theory, a lot about international relations, and a lot of factual information about nuclear weapons (how they work, how they're used, and the risks they pose).

Nuclear politics was an excellent course; highly recommend for those interested in national security, game theory, and international relations. The course is a great blend between understanding why states proliferate, how they proliferate, and the history of nuclear (counter)proliferation. Professor Debs is a great professor, and he is genuinely enthused by the content at hand. The essays and response memos were also very interesting assignments, and I learned a lot just from doing them. Readings were manageable as well.
I learned about every major nuclear crisis and nuclearization program and acquired the theoretical knowledge to understand them.
I learned more about global affairs pertaining to military strategy.
I learned a history of nuclear developments and was able to put arguments together to create my own opinions.
History of nuclear weapons, factors that cause proliferation, and current debates about nuclear issues
A strong understanding of past nuclear crises, theories of nuclear deterrence, case studies of proliferation, and theoretical frameworks to understand why countries choose to proliferate
History of nuclear weapons, dilemmas, proliferation, theories about the future of nuclear weapons

I learned a lot about the politics of nuclear weapons from multiple perspectives. The course begins as a broad overview of nuclear weapons, and it then homes in on particular aspects of it (supply side, demand side, case studies, etc).
N/a

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: 
- The professor is clearly very knowledgeable about the subject. I liked that we read directly from his book. 
- I really like the discussions at the end of every class, although the same students seemed to mainly participate every class. 

Weaknesses: 
- The grading seemed a bit arbitrary, especially since it's all done by the TA. Since we weren't given averages or letter grades, I had no way of interpreting my grades. More guidelines or distribution info would've been appreciated. 
- I think that pretty much no one did all the reading. Realistically with 3+ other classes, we probably can't read 40-60 pages in depth between each class, especially if we're discussing them in the next class. 
- I didn't love the format of the lecture itself. It just wasn't super engaging some of the time. I think it would be better if the discussions were a bit more interspersed and there was more of a norm of calling on students and asking questions throughout the lecture.

Many, many strengths. The students in the class were my favorite part; so many peers with great interests and experiences in national security and high stakes international relations. The essays were challenging, and graded fairly reasonably (a tad harsher than the average political science course.) I do wish that broad questions were asked to the class from time to time, where we could brainstorm together, and then be told why we were wrong/right.
The format of the course, lectures with a discussion component, was great.
The combination of the theory and practical cases

Strengths: well organized, cohesive content
Weaknesses: unclear expectations, inconsistent engagement
It was very engaging. Lectures were very well done

Strengths: extremely interesting content, professor is very chill and great at explaining the concepts, readings are actually interesting, workload is not bad. small class size means theres both lecture and discussion 
Weaknesses: sometimes class can be a repeat of the concepts covered in the readings
Strengths of this course are the professor and the material. Class discussions often felt a bit disjointed because the class was larger than a typical discussion section.

Professor Debs is without question one of the best part about this course: he is really passionate and really cares about his students! I thought the format of the class was interesting (lecture with the last 15-25 minutes saved for discussion and debate). It did feel like the workload was much higher than probably necessary and at times it felt a bit overwhelming, especially for the weeks you were assignment a memo. The final debate statement also did feel like a lot. Perhaps having only one memo assignment and reducing the final debate statement by a few pages would help alleviate this!
N/a

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is a very interesting course where you will learn A LOT about the history of nuclear proliferation and the theory behind it. Although it can get a little dry in the middle, Professor Debs usually shows some cool videos about Nuclear Politics that you might find interesting and that will keep you motivated for class.
Yes. It wasn't too hard but was pretty interesting. I would just tell them to skim the reading.
I would recommend it, highly. There was a good mix of class years (many older students), even though this was an intro class -- so just be prepared for that! The content was accessible nonetheless.
Yes, the course provides a great foundation for understanding nuclear weapons in international relations today
Yes, its interesting, the assignments facilitate learning and engage with class material, and the workload is super manageable. Plus, Professor Debs is great.
I would not recommend this course to another student. While I did learn some useful and interesting information, this course was really difficult to engage with.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in discovering the history of nuclear weapons and politics, or for anyone wanting to explore the topic.
I would. One of my favorite classes taken
Absolutely, if you're into foreign policy/security/etc - really interesting content, chill professor, and not too bad workload

If you are even remotely interested in nuclear weapons and their implications for international relations, you should definitely take this course. Professor Debs is really awesome and he is a great professor who really cares about his students. The material is really interesting but, at times in the middle of the semester, some of the topics can feel a bit dry as they get really technical and analytical. Overall, though, the course is really good and I am glad I took it!
N/a
